text:
I’ve been using FileTrees.jl quite a lot over the past couple of months, and am really liking it. I don’t know the python ecosystem well enough to be sure, but it looks like there isn’t any kind of high-level api with similar plan-optimization functionality in python land. (The python multiprocessing scripts I’ve seen seem to require more technical knowledge and tend not to be as compact.)

If this is indeed the case, I think that we should brag about FileTrees (and Dagger) more when talking about Julia’s advantages --- a lot of folks wanting to scale things up on a cluster tend not to have formal training in computer architecture etc, and this is the kind of thing that’d really appeal to them. (And it’d presumably make things quite a bit easier even for experienced folks.)

If this is indeed the case, I think that we should brag about FileTrees (and Dagger) more when talking about Julia’s advantages --- a lot of folks wanting to scale things up on a cluster tend not to have formal training in computer architecture etc, and this is the kind of thing that’d really appeal to them. text: I agree, people should be bragging about our distributed computing story. It's mostly my fault that I haven't encouraged people to do that :smile:  I'm aiming to give a JuliaCon talk about using Dagger to build applications, so that should help encourage people to try it out.

elements.text: I agree, people should be bragging about our distributed computing story. It's mostly my fault that I haven't encouraged people to do that
I'm aiming to give a JuliaCon talk about using Dagger to build applications, so that should help encourage people to try it out.

text: After thinking a bit more about it, I think the point I wanted to make was this. *If* it is indeed much easier to do common sorts of distributed data wrangling with FileTrees than in Python, then that would show the following. Contrary to the oft-repeated claim that it’s only worth using Julia if you need to do custom things or need cutting-edge stuff in somewhat niche fields, Julia can in fact be helpful even for very run-of-the-mill things like reading a ton of xml files in your filetree and lazily wrangling them. You can do that with FileTrees without knowing much about computer architecture or distributed computing; and even if you do know all those things, you’d still be more productive using something higher-level like FileTrees

If this is indeed the case, I think that we should brag about FileTrees (and Dagger) more when talking about Julia’s advantages --- a lot of folks wanting to scale things up on a cluster tend not to have formal training in computer architecture etc, and this is the kind of thing that’d really appeal to them. If this is indeed the case, I think that we should brag about FileTrees (and Dagger) more when talking about Julia’s advantages --- a lot of folks wanting to scale things up on a cluster tend not to have formal training in computer architecture etc, and this is the kind of thing that’d really appeal to them. After thinking a bit more about it, I think the point I wanted to make was this.
If

it is indeed much easier to do common sorts of distributed data wrangling with FileTrees than in Python, then that would show the following. Contrary to the oft-repeated claim that it’s only worth using Julia if you need to do custom things or need cutting-edge stuff in somewhat niche fields, Julia can in fact be helpful even for very run-of-the-mill things like reading a ton of xml files in your filetree and lazily wrangling them. You can do that with FileTrees without knowing much about computer architecture or distributed computing; and even if you do know all those things, you’d still be more productive using something higher-level like FileTrees

text: Have you seen dask?

elements.text: Have you seen dask?

text: Dask has a lot of rough edges that make me pine for something like Dagger or FileTrees :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Dask has a lot of rough edges that make me pine for something like Dagger or FileTrees

text: Really? I haven't used dask but that's amazing since it's had many many more   people hours put into it

elements.text: Really? I haven't used dask but that's amazing since it's had many many more   people hours put into it

text: It's somewhat held back by pandas/numpy and needing to maintain compat with both. The higher-level API is certainly hard to match, but it doesn't take much to feel the 2-language problem when working with it

elements.text: It's somewhat held back by pandas/numpy and needing to maintain compat with both. The higher-level API is certainly hard to match, but it doesn't take much to feel the 2-language problem when working with it

text: Yeah, dask has the problem of being tied to Python, so they have to reinvent the world for anything to be chunked or distributed in fancy ways.

elements.text: Yeah, dask has the problem of being tied to Python, so they have to reinvent the world for anything to be chunked or distributed in fancy ways.

text: Dagger is also surprisingly similar internally to dask, so we can trivially match whatever features they have

elements.text: Dagger is also surprisingly similar internally to dask, so we can trivially match whatever features they have

text: I was thinking of the higher level collection APIs vs filetrees. I can definitely see how custom stuff would be better in dagger

elements.text: I was thinking of the higher level collection APIs vs filetrees. I can definitely see how custom stuff would be better in dagger

text: I'm not completely convinced that the dask model of partitioning along one dimension and running everything else eagerly is the best one either. Part of the reason people use it in the first place is to work around Python's lack of thread parallelism, so :shrugging:

elements.text: I'm not completely convinced that the dask model of partitioning along one dimension and running everything else eagerly is the best one either. Part of the reason people use it in the first place is to work around Python's lack of thread parallelism, so
